title: Rugby World Cup: The odds on who will win the Webb Ellis Cup
text:

The countdown to the knockout stages of the Rugby World Cup is underway.

All eight teams will have optimism filling the air around them as some hope to upset the odds while others will be looking to prove why they are the favourites.

England, Wales and Ireland will be representing the Home Nations as they have their eyes set on the Webb Ellis Cup and a trip to Yokohoma in November.

With the drama of Typhoon Hagibis causing cancellations and the threat of legal action against World Rugby, it was a dramatic end to the Pool stage of the tournament.

Fortunately, the typhoon did not disrupt the tournament as much as previously feared.

Our friends at The Pools have compiled the World Cup odds from the remaining teams in the Rugby World Cup:

New Zealand - 5/4

Back them here

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

The favourites. No surprise really.

The All-Blacks missed out on completing a 100% run after their final Pool game against Italy was cancelled due to Typhoon Hagibis meaning the match was awarded as a draw.

Head coach Steve Hansen will have his eyes on an unprecedented third consecutive World Cup victory but they face Ireland in the quarter-finals.

South Africa - 3/1

Back them here

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

South Africa have the ingredients for the perfect revenge dish.

After losing to Japan in arguably the greatest match on the World Cup stage (or any stage for that matter) now have the chance to knock-out their opponents on their own turf.

The Japanese defence will need to keep a close eye on South Africa's pace - especially Cheslin Kolbe because my word can he run!

Let's hope both sides have kept their notes from last month's friendly.

England - 4/1

Back them here

Eddie Jones' team look untroubled. The cancellation in their final Pool game against France might have frustrated some fans but the extra rest could benefit England greatly.

The side's maturity will be tested as they face an Australia side when Michael Cheika attempts to create a siege mentality amongst the Wallabies.

England will need to utilise Owen Farrell for his best game yet if they are to go through to the semi-finals.

Wales - 8/1

Back them here

(Image: Getty Images)

Wales keep on grinding results and have rightly gone through to the quarter-final stages as Pool winners - the first time since 1999.

Warren Gatland witnessed his side wake up against Georgia; get battered against Australia; take on a complacent Fiji side and cruise by Uruguay.

All while coming away with 100% win record in the competition - they now face France who have had the advantage of having their match against England cancelled so more time to prepare for their quarter-final clash.

Naturally, Wales will need Alun Wyn Jones on his best form - he is their leader after all.

Ireland 16/1

Back them here

(Image: Getty)

After flirting with the number one ranking position, Ireland have returned as a team under the radar.

They have managed to go through the Pool stages with the odd banana skin of losing in a close-fought defeat to Japan before the hosts beat Scotland in their last game to give the Irish a place in the quarter-final.

They could not have asked for a more difficult tie when they face New Zealand in Tokyo but Ireland are not unfamiliar with a win over the All Blacks.

They know what they can offer and the All Blacks do not like it.

Australia 20/1

Back them here

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

The Wallabies have not exactly dazzled during this competition.

The Aussies come into this as a team underrated which could well benefit Michael Cheika's squad if England's mature heads are not in the game.

David Pocock played a blinder in the last World Cup and, at the age of 31, looks like the number 8 is giving his all for one last chance to become a world champion.

Japan 33/1

Back them here

(Image: REUTERS)

The hosts have warmed the hearts of every neutral going in the sport - and caused pandamonium in every street, town and city across Japan when they beat Scotland last weekend.

They successfully won the group stage and are only the second nation with a 100% record so far after Typhoon Hagibis nearly disrupted their last Pool game.

Yu Tamura is their key man with 48 points from the fly-half and will be crucial in their match against 2007 winners South Africa.

France 33/1

Back them here

(Image: FRANCK FIFE/AFP via Getty Images)

Safe to say, France are a team with fickle performances and can go from one extreme to the other and their quarter-final opponents Wales found that out in their Six Nations clash.

France can be an unbreakable force and an immovable object at the same time - as Wales discovered in the first-half.

Or they can just show their complacency and hand their opponents the win on a plate - as Wales discovered in the second-half.
